englishTranslation: Look around where you are going!
That day you are going to the place.
vocabIncluded: al: "to the" before a masculine noun
he: "have", "I have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person)

englishTranslation: I think they are going to the place.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
al: "to the" before a masculine noun

spanishExample: No va *because* no había estado bien.
englishTranslation: She isn’t going because she had not been well.
vocabIncluded: "bien": adverb meaning "well", "fine", and a variety of other positive things
había: "had", "he/she/it had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 3rd person)

spanishExample: No vamos con ellas y ellas no van con nosotras.
englishTranslation: We aren’t going with them(f) and they(f) aren’t going with us(f).
vocabIncluded: ella: "them" after a preposition (fem. prep. pronoun)

spanishExample: Para *next week* él habrá *talked* con ella.
englishTranslation: By next week he will have talked with her.
vocabIncluded: "para": "by" a moment in time, as in "by then"
habrá: "will have", "he/she/it will have" before a participle (Haber, future, 3rd person)

englishTranslation: She wants to go to the place.
vocabIncluded: al: "to the" before a masculine noun

spanishExample: Usted está yendo a *where* nosotros habíamos ido.
englishTranslation: You (formal) are going to where we had gone.
vocabIncluded: habíamos: "had", "we had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 1st person plural)
usted: "you", formal subject pronoun, taking 3rd-person treatment
han: "have", "they have" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person plural)
ustedes: "you" plural, subject pronoun (3rd-person plural treatment)

englishTranslation: You all know that I’m going to the place.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
al: "to the" before a masculine noun
ustedes: "you" plural, subject pronoun (3rd-person plural treatment)

spanishExample: Ustedes *have* que ir a la casa con él.
englishTranslation: You all have to go to the house with him.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation
ustedes: "you" plural, subject pronoun (3rd-person plural treatment)

spanishExample: Vamos al lugar *where* habías ido con él.
englishTranslation: We’re going to the place where you had gone with him.
vocabIncluded: al: "to the" before a masculine noun
habías: "had", "you had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Van a ese lugar *because* no habían estado *there before.*
englishTranslation: They are going to that place because they hadn’t been there before.
vocabIncluded: habían: "had", "they had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Vas a la casa para hacer algo para mí.
englishTranslation: You’re going to the house in order to make something for me.
vocabIncluded: para: "in order", "in order to" before an infinitive

spanishExample: Voy con ellos, pero no había ido *before.*
englishTranslation: I’m going with them, but I hadn’t gone before.
vocabIncluded: había: "had", "I had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 1st person)

spanishExample: Yo había hecho esto para ti.
englishTranslation: I had made this for you.
vocabIncluded: había: "had", "I had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 1st person)
